book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text:
Works of Al-Hajjawi, a collection containing four treatises:
1/ A rule on knowing Iraqi Ritls via Damascene weights and those of other horizon lands.
2/ A Fatwa on a question regarding Riba (selling kneaded dates) and the arbitration between Al-Shuwayki and Ibn Atwa regarding it.
3/ An answer regarding the relied-upon book in the School (Madhab).
4/ A poem on the rulings of Ablution (Wudu) and Prayer.
By Sheikh Musa bin Ahmed Al-Hajjawi Al-Hanbali (Died 968 AH).
Cared for and edited by: Prof. Dr. Abdul Salam bin Muhammad Al-Shuway'ir.
foot_note: None

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text:
Praise be to Allah, and I bear witness that there is no deity but Allah, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger, may Allah bless him and his family and grant them peace. As for what follows:
This is a collection containing four treatises from the works of Sheikh Musa Al-Hajjawi (Died 968 AH). I sought to publish it after Allah the Almighty granted success in publishing his first book (Sharh Manzumat Al-Adab) in the year 1425 AH. They are three treatises which Allah the Almighty bestowed upon me the opportunity to seek their publication after they remained hostage to two prisons (Obscurity and the Book Cabinet), as they were not mentioned in manuscript catalogs, and historians did not count them among the works of the scholar Sheikh Musa bin Ahmed Al-Hajjawi, despite their undeniable importance.
The treatises are:
1/ A rule on knowing Iraqi Ritls via Damascene weights, and those of other horizon lands.
2/ A Fatwa on a question regarding Riba.
3/ An answer by Sheikh Musa Al-Hajjawi regarding the relied-upon book in the School (Madhab).
4/ And the fourth of these treatises: A poem on the rulings of Ablution (Wudu) and Prayer.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: As for the first treatise: It speaks about the measures of Ritls, their differences, and their adjustment using Dirhams. In it, the author compared Iraqi Ritls with other Ritls of horizon lands; such as the Damascene, Egyptian, Laythi, Alexandrian, Baalbaki, Tabarani, Jerusalemite (Qudsi), Nabulsi, Himsi, Aleppine (Halabi), Beiruti, Hamawi, Basri, Makki, Madani, and others. Thus, this treatise—despite its small size—preserved for us important information regarding the difference between these Ritls in weight, which we rarely find in the printed books circulating in our hands. In addition to adjusting these Ritls and calculating how to convert measures to them using other legal measures; such as the Sa', the Two Qullas (Qullatayn), and the like. It also shows us the method of the scholars of the tenth century in some mathematical problems and algebra with two unknowns. The Ritl is used as a unit of volume (Kayl) mostly, and it may be used as a unit of weight in certain instances (1).
foot_note: 1. Abu al-Abbas al-Azafi al-Sabti (633 AH) said in his book [Ithbat Ma Laisa Minhu Budd, p. 142]: (The Ritl is a masculine noun, pronounced with a Fatha on the Ra or a Kasra. It is a name for a quantity of weighed items estimated by custom, not by original linguistic placement. It is also a name for what weighed items are calibrated with, made of iron, copper, lead, or stone. It may also be a name for what is used to measure volume, like the Mudd and the Sa'). Al-Azhari said in [Al-Muzhir]: (It is both a measure of volume and weight).

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: However, in the terminology of later jurists and the usage of common people, it is considered one of the types of volume measures known in previous eras (1) with which liquids and other things are measured (2). The amount of the (Ritl) and its volume varies according to the convention of the people of the regions; as Al-Jurjani mentioned in (Al-Ta'rifat) (3). Sheikh Abu Al-Hasan Al-Mawardi (Died 450 AH) said: (The people of every region have agreed upon Ritls that differ in increase and decrease... and in localities, there are different Ritls used for transactions in the markets, and I have not heard that the Ritl of one town matched another except rarely) (4). Al-Shirazi said: (The people of every region and country have agreed in transactions upon Ritls that differ in increase and decrease, especially the people of the Levant specifically) (5).
foot_note:
1. Ibn Muflih mentioned in [Al-Furu' 4/77] that the estimation of volume measures was transferred to weight so that it would be preserved and transmitted.
2. Dr. Sameh Fahmi mentions in his book (Al-Makayil fi Sadr al-Islam, p. 46) that the Ritl is a measure for liquids only; inferring from the poet's saying: 'She has a Ritl in which she measures oil ... and a farmer driving a donkey with it.' But this inference does not rise to the level of restricting this measure to liquids only, for many heritage texts have come measuring meat, bread, and other things by the Ritl, which indicates that the Ritl is a measure not exclusive to liquids only.
3. Al-Ta'rifat by Al-Jurjani, p. 240.
4. Al-Rutba fi Talab al-Hisba, by Al-Mawardi, p. 168, 173.
5. Nihayat al-Rutba, p. 15.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: Ibn Al-Ukhuwwa (Died 729 AH) said: (The Ritl has much difference in the metropolises and countries... and I have not heard that the Ritl of a country matched another town except rarely, or a village matching a village of no consequence) (1). Ibn Al-Humam (Died 861 AH) said: (The Ritl and the Uqiyyah are differed upon by the custom of the metropolises, and within a single metropolis, the matter of sold goods differs) (2). Indeed, it was mentioned that the people of a single town deal with more than one Ritl; for meat and for bread there is a different Ritl, and they differ from the Ritl of other needs, and so on (3). Even Ibn Duraid, the well-known linguist (Died 321 AH), said: (The Ritl is a measure whose amount I do not know) (4). This difference in volume measures (and likewise the difference in circulating weights) causes much confusion and difficulty; therefore, Omar bin Abdul Aziz (Died 101 AH) intended to unify the volume measures and weights, as it was reported that he wrote to his workers: (We see that the perfection of the land's measure and its scale is that it be one in the entire land) (5).
foot_note:
1. Ma'alim Al-Qurba, by Ibn Al-Ukhuwwa, p. 82.
2. Fath Al-Qadir 7/17.
3. The previous source.
4. Ithbat Ma Laisa Minhu Budd, p. 135.
5. Narrated by Ibn Abd al-Hakam in (Sirat Omar bin Abdul Aziz 'Ala Ma Rawahu Malik wa Ashabuhu, p. 87).

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: This matter, even if it was not accomplished in that time politically (and was accomplished centuries later), the Muslim scholars did not neglect this aspect its due right of research and examination. This was not limited to those who wrote on arithmetic and algebra only, but extended to the jurists of the Sharia and its scholars, so they cared about the differences between Ritls and their measures. We see many of them talking about this subject in jurisprudential books, books of Sharia politics, or in the books of scribes and land-tax (Kharaj) officers, and even in travelogues as well. Professor Ahmad Faris Al-Shidyaq mentions when he visited Britain in the year 1848 AD the amount of the English Ritl and that it equals about 150 Dirhams (1), and in doing so, he was following the sunnah of the predecessors, for the book of Al-Maqdisi preserved for us many of these measures until it was considered an important reference for many who wrote on this subject.
foot_note: 1. Kashf Al-Mukhabba 'An Tamaddun Urubba, Ahmad Faris Al-Shidyaq, p. 91.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: Muslim jurists were concerned with defining the amounts of units of volume and weight with a clear, distinct definition for fear of falling into sin and fraud (Tatfif), and this was entrusted to the Muhtasibs (market inspectors) and made one of their duties. As for their concern with estimating the volume of the Ritl specifically, it is because the jurists relied on it and made it a standard for volume. Abu Muhammad Ibn Al-Qattan (Died after 647 AH) said: (We only looked into the meaning of the Ritl from the perspective of understanding the mentioned Mudd, not because it occurs in the wording of the Prophet (peace be upon him) in this chapter or in others) (1). And this treatise is but one of the efforts of the scholars in this chapter.
foot_note: 1. Quoted from him by: Al-Khuzai in (Takhrij Al-Dalalat Al-Sam'iyyah, p. 615).

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: The Second Treatise authored by Sheikh Musa Al-Hajjawi: A Fatwa the Sheikh was asked about regarding dates if they are kneaded and become a paste; are they considered weighed or measured by volume? And subsequently, is it valid to sell these kneaded dates for weighed meat? Or not? Discussion on this issue abounded among Hanbali jurists at that time; such as the Sheikhs Al-Shuwayki Al-Dimashqi, Ahmed bin Atwa, Abdullah bin Rahma the two Najdis, and others from those before and after them who were contemporary to this issue. I have collected their names and their words in the footnotes of this treatise. Sheikh Musa wrote this brief treatise to arbitrate between his two sheikhs, Al-Shuwayki and Ahmed bin Yahya bin Atwa. Perhaps this fatwa complements the research of this issue by the notable jurists of the School of Imam Ahmed at that time, and is the final knot in it—as I reckon—for I have not found it raised after him. The Third Treatise: An answer to a question Sheikh Musa Al-Hajjawi was asked, regarding if there is a contradiction between what he wrote in "Al-Iqna" and in "Hashiyat Al-Tanqih", with what is in "Al-Tanqih" by Al-Mardawi? Which one takes precedence? Then a comment by the scholar Sheikh Muhammad Ibn Dhahlan on this fatwa.
foot_note: None

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: Ibn Manqour supported Al-Hajjawi's answer and said about it: (He has spoken truthfully and fairly). It is a brief answer to the question, but it has great importance which is evident. The Fourth Treatise: A poem on the conditions of Ablution (Wudu) and its obligatory acts, the conditions of Ghusl, the conditions of Tayammum, the conditions of Prayer, the pillars of Prayer, and the conditions of Imamate. The total number of its verses is 31 verses. I have sought to publish these treatises hoping for benefit from them. I ask Allah the Almighty for sincerity in word and deed, and to grant us understanding in His religion. May Allah bless and grant peace to our Prophet Muhammad and his family and all his companions.
foot_note: None

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: Introduction to the Author (1): * His Name and Lineage: He is the scholar, Sharaf al-Din Abu al-Naja Musa bin Ahmed bin Musa bin Salim bin Isa bin Salim Al-Hajjawi, Al-Maqdisi, then Al-Salihi, Al-Dimashqi, Al-Hanbali. The Mufti of the Hanbalis in (Damascus), and the pillar of the later scholars of the Hanbalis. * His Birth: Sheikh Musa was born in the year (895 AH) in "Hajja"—with a Fatha on the Ha, and a Shadda on the open Jeem—; one of the districts of Nablus. * His Sheikhs: Sheikh Musa read under a group of sheikhs and scholars of his era; Ibn Humayd said: "He traveled to Damascus and lived in (The School of Sheikh al-Islam Abu Umar), and read under the sheikhs of his time." Among those whom (Sheikh Musa Al-Hajjawi) was a student of: - Ahmed bin Muhammad Al-Shuwayki Al-Nabulsi (939 AH).
foot_note: 1. This biography is taken in summary from the introduction of my editing of Sharh Manzumat Al-Adab by the author.

text: Description of the Manuscript, and Method of Work (1) The First Treatise: First: Description of the Manuscript: I relied in publishing this treatise on a unique manuscript preserved in the library of (Princeton) in the United States of America under number (375 B). A photocopy of it is in the King Fahd National Library in Riyadh, and I obtained this manuscript through them, so may Allah reward them with good, and they have my prayers and praise. This manuscript is appended to a manuscript by Al-Jara'i and bound with it, so the cataloger did not notice it to identify it. The manuscript consists of (6) pages. It was written in the year 966 AH (i.e., during the author's life, and two years before his death) and was written by his student Muhammad bin Ahmed Al-Kurdi Al-Salihi. It is a good copy in general, were it not for the omission of some words and sentences, which I tried to establish in the text based on calculation results. Second: Establishing its attribution to the author: Establishing this treatise to the author is one of the important issues; because attributing a saying

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: to its speaker gives the saying benefit and strength. Several things indicate the attribution of this treatise to Sheikh Musa bin Ahmed Al-Hajjawi, including: First: What was established on the first page of the manuscript regarding its attribution to its author, along with the fact that the manuscript copying occurred during the author's life. Second: The similarity of the style of this treatise with his other works of Sheikh Musa, by his care in it for the Hanbali school, in addition to the similarity of the idea of this treatise with his commentary on the book (Al-Tanqih Al-Mushbi') by Al-Mardawi. Added to that is what is seen of Sheikh Musa's care for this particular part in more than one place in his works (1), other than what he dictated in this brief treatise. Third: Naming the treatise: I did not find a name for this treatise in the manuscript, nor did I find its name in the books of biographers, so I gave it a name taken from the author's introduction, for he said: (This is a useful rule—God Willing—benefiting the beginner, and aiding the advanced scholar in knowing Iraqi Ritls via Damascene weights, and others of the horizon lands).
foot_note: 1. See: Hawashi Al-Tanqih pp. 77-78, 92, Al-Iqna' 1/13, and see also: Kashshaf Al-Qina' 3/400.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: (2) The Second Treatise: First: Description of the Manuscript: I relied in publishing this treatise on an original manuscript preserved in the Central Library at Imam Muhammad bin Saud Islamic University in Riyadh, consisting of two pages, and neither the scribe's name nor the date of copying was mentioned in it. The treatise is located on two pages in Naskh script, and the paper is late industrial paper, and I think it was written at the end of the thirteenth century at the latest, or the beginning of the fourteenth. Second: Establishing its attribution to the author: This treatise contains in its content what indicates the validity of its attribution to Sheikh Musa Al-Hajjawi. In addition to the explicit declaration of attributing this Fatwa to Sheikh Musa Al-Hajjawi on the cover, it contains quotes from two of the author's sheikhs, namely Al-Shuwayki and Ibn Atwa; as will come in the documentation. It also addresses a famous issue at that time among Hanbali jurists in general, and the jurists of Damascus and Najd in particular.

text: (3) The Third Treatise: First: Description of the Manuscript: I relied in publishing this treatise on a benefit written on the margin of one of the original handwritten copies preserved in Riyadh. This answer is written in the margin of the book. Second: Establishing its attribution to the author: The content of this answer indicates the validity of its attribution to Al-Hajjawi, especially since Sheikh Ahmed Ibn Manqour transmitted it with the chain of transmission (Isnad) to him. (4) The Fourth Treatise: First: Description of the Manuscript: These verses are appended to the manuscript preserved in the Egyptian National Library under number 739 Majami', on the face of folio 20 and its back. The credit after Allah for noticing it and publishing it goes to Mr. Saleh bin Muhammad bin Abdul Fattah, where he published it in his book (Al-Taqyidat Al-Shahiyya p. 177), and I benefited from it in publishing it. Second: Establishing its attribution to the author: These verses are attributed to Sheikh Musa, and he is known for his prolific poetry, just as the content of the verses is consistent with the Hanbali school, and contains issues considered among his unique views (Mufradat).

text: Third: Method of Work in Editing: I transcribed the manuscripts and corrected the distortion or omission that occurred in them, which are few places, pointing them out in the footnote. This is because the first treatise relies on calculation in many of its parts, and perhaps the scribe had a lapse of sight and dropped some words or sentences, so I established them in the text between brackets [], with a reference to that in the footnote. As for the third treatise, the comments cited by the scribe, I established them in the footnote as they are. Then I commented after that on some places that I saw were of importance in that regard. A Rule on Knowing Iraqi Ritls via Damascene Weights, and other Horizon Lands
By the Jurist Sheikh Musa bin Salim Al-Hajjawi Al-Hanbali (Died 968 AH)
Cared for, edited and commented upon by: Prof. Dr. Abdul Salam bin Muhammad Al-Shuway'ir
foot_note: None

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text:
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful
Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds. And may Allah bless our Master Muhammad and his family and all his companions.. To proceed.
This is a useful rule (1) —Allah the Almighty Willing—benefiting the beginner, and aiding the advanced scholar in knowing Iraqi Ritls (2) via Damascene weights, and others of the
foot_note:
1. The author summarized these topics in a rule he mentioned in (Hawashi Al-Tanqih p. 78) saying: (A rule from which Iraqi weights are known by the Egyptian, Damascene, Jerusalemite, Aleppine, and Ba'li Ritl. If you add to the Iraqi weights in the Two Qullas and others a like amount five times and a quarter of a like amount, then take one-seventh of the total, it is the Egyptian. If you add a like amount of an eighth, then take one-seventh of the total, it is the Jerusalemite. If you add a like amount of a quarter, then take one-seventh of the total, it is the Aleppine. And if you take one-seventh of the Iraqi without increase, it is the Ba'li).
2. Estimation was restricted to Iraqi Ritls; because the early Hanbali authors used to estimate volume with them; and most of them were Hanbalis of Iraq; among them for example: Abu Ali Ibn Abi Musa (Died 428 AH) in (Al-Irshad p. 21), Abu Al-Khattab Al-Kalwadhani (Died 510 AH) in (Al-Hidayah 1/11), Al-Samari (Died 616 AH) in (Al-Mustaw'ib 1/10), Al-Ba'qubi (617 AH), Ibn Tamim (Died 675 AH) in (Mukhtasarihi 1/36), Abu Talib Al-Basri (Died 684 AH) in (Al-Hawi Al-Saghir p. 20), and (Al-Hawi Al-Kabir 1/77, 142), Ibn Hamdan (Died 695 AH) in (Al-Ri'ayah Al-Sughra 1/328), Al-Dujayli (Died 732 AH) in (Al-Wajiz 1/113). They were followed by Al-Muwaffaq Ibn Qudamah (620 AH) in his books (Al-Kafi 1/17), (Al-Mughni), and (Al-Muqni'). As for (Al-Umdah), he estimated it by the Damascene. This is what the Damascene Hanbali authors followed; such as: Yusuf Ibn Abdul Hadi (Died 909 AH) in (Al-Durr Al-Naqi 1/50), Ibn Al-Najjar in (Al-Muntaha 1/21), and Ibn Balban (Died 1083 AH) in (Akhsar Al-Mukhtasarat 1/45 with Kashf Al-Mukhaddarat). While the Egyptian Hanbali authors relied on estimating the Two Qullas by the Egyptian Ritl; such as Al-Bahuti (Died 1059 AH) in (Umdat Al-Fiqh p. 11), and Ibn Qa'id Al-Najdi then Al-Masri in (Hidayat Al-Raghib 1/20). As for the Ba'li Hanbalis, they mentioned the previous three together, and added to them its estimation by the Ba'li Ritl; like Muhammad Ibn Balban Al-Ba'li (Died 1083 AH) in (Kafi Al-Mubtadi p.), and Ahmed Al-Ba'li (Died 1083 AH) in (Al-Rawd Al-Nadi 1/27). As for the Harranis, they mentioned them by the Harrani Ritl, like Ibn Tamim in (Mukhtasarihi 3/248).

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: horizon lands. Knowing this depends on knowing the weight of the (Iraqi Ritl) in the Wazni Dirham (1); because the Wazni Dirham did not differ in Jahiliyyah nor Islam (2), so for that reason, precision was based on it in Iraqi volume measures; because their origin is volume, but they transferred that to weight so it would be preserved; because volume measures change a lot, while weight does not
foot_note:
1. "Al-Dirham Al-Wazni" and it is called the Dirham of Kayl (volume), which is the Dirham minted by Abd al-Malik bin Marwan.
2. Wahb bin Kaysan said: (I saw Dinars and Dirhams before Abd al-Malik engraved them, blank. They are the weight of the Dinars that Abd al-Malik minted). See: Futuh Al-Buldan by Al-Baladhuri p. 472, Al-Kharaj wa Al-Nuzum Al-Maliyah by Dr. Muhammad Diya' Al-Rayyes p. 343. Ibn Zhahira mentioned in (Kifayat Al-Muhtaj p. 321) that this is called the Dirham of Kayl; because the legal Dirham is composed of it, and its amount is fifty grains and two-fifths of a grain.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: change; as preceded (1). The weights mentioned in the books of Fiqh (2), and others regarding the Two Qullas (Qullatayn) and others regarding the amount of water used for ablution and Ghusl (3), and the Nisab (minimum amount) of Zakat for grains, fruits (4), honey (5), expiations (Kaffarat), and Zakat al-Fitr (6),
foot_note:
1. Jurists estimated volume measures by weight; due to the lack of an agreed-upon measure for area among the ancients, as the sizes of volume measures often change; Al-Hajjawi (the author of this treatise) said in his book (Hawashi Tanqih p. 127): (The Wasq, the Sa', and the Mudd are volume measures that were transferred to weight because they are not consistent). This issue—estimating volume measures by weight—was and still is a point of confusion for many jurists, to the point that Ibn Al-Fakhar Al-Qurtubi Al-Maliki (Died 419 AH) said objecting to those who did that: (The measured volume is not known by weight, and weight is not known by measured volume, and whatever was originally weight, the volume in it is unknown) [Al-Tabsira fi Naqd Al-Risala by Ibn Al-Fakhar p. 108].
2. Sheikh Taqi al-Din mentioned that the custom of the Prophet (peace be upon him) was to estimate measurable things by their vessels; like the Sa', the Wasq, the Qillas, and the like [Al-Fatawa Al-Kubra 1/216].
3. One needs to know the volume in the chapters of purification to estimate the water that does not carry impurity, which is what exceeds two Qullas. And to know the amount with which it is recommended to perform ablution, which is a Mudd, or to perform Ghusl with, which is a Sa'.
4. The amount mentioned in the text for Zakat of grains is (The Wasq).
5. This is a branch based on the disagreement of jurists regarding Zakat on honey. The well-known view of the Hanbali school is the obligation of Zakat on it and that its Nisab is ten Faraqs, each Faraq being sixty Ritls. [Masa'il Al-Kawsaj 1/275, Al-Sharh Al-Kabir and Al-Insaf 6/567].
6. Expiations, Zakat of produce from the earth, and Zakat al-Fitr are estimated by the unit of Sa' or half of it, or by the Mudd and its double, depending on the type of expiation, while observing the disagreement of scholars on that, and the type of food given.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: and other than that (1) are indeed by the Iraqi [Standard] (2). So the people of every country needed to know these weights. If their Ritl agrees with them; i.e., by the amount of their weights; like Baghdad, they sufficed with mentioning it. And if their Ritl is different; like most countries, then they are in need of
foot_note:
1. Like estimating the Kharaj (land tax), and the amount of Jizyah on the People of the Covenant (Dhimma) and those under the same ruling. And like estimating the Dowry (Mahr), for Ishaq Al-Harbi said: (The Sunnah is marriage for a Ritl).
2. Al-Hajjawi mentioned here that the Ritl mentioned in the books of jurists is indeed the Iraqi Ritl. This is true, as estimation by the Iraqi Ritl is predominant among jurists, to the point that Al-Muhibb Al-Tabari said: (It is the Legal [Shar'i] Ritl) [Kifayat Al-Akhyar 1/382]. However, Ibn Muflih mentioned in (Al-Mubdi' 3/381) that the Iraqi Ritl was not in the text of Ahmed, but rather the Meccan one was. Among the texts from Imam Ahmed regarding estimating the Ritl, is what Al-Athram narrated, he said: Abu Abdullah was asked: If he took thirteen and a third Ritls of flour, baked it, and divided the bread among ten poor people? He said: (I prefer what the bread came to be a Mudd of wheat, and I hope this suffices him) [Al-Riwayatayn wa Al-Wajhayn by Judge Abu Ya'la 2/188]. In (Masa'il Abdullah p. 170) I said: How many Ritls is the Sa'? He said: (We estimated it as five Ritls and a third of wheat). Imam Ahmed also said: (The Mudd is a Ritl and a third) [Masa'il Abdullah p. 186, Masa'il Harb 188 manuscript]. Abdullah said [his Masa'il 389]: I asked my father: About a man who bequeathed that expiations for oaths be paid on his behalf, how should it be given in charity? He said: (The least of oaths is three oaths, each poor person is given at least a Mudd of wheat; which is a Ritl and a third of flour, or three Ritls minus a third of dates for every poor person). In (Masa'il of his son Salih 189): I said: How many Ritls is the Sa'? He said: (We estimated it, so it is five Ritls and a third of wheat or dates).

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: knowing it by their Ritl and their weights; because it is better known to them. So controls and rules were made for that, all returning to calculation (arithmetic). And it is necessary for whoever desires that to know the amount of the Ritls of the two countries; the Iraqi as preceded, and the other, the Ritl of the country for which knowledge of the Iraqi is sought (1). [Determining the Iraqi Ritl] (2) The weight of the Iraqi Ritl is one hundred and twenty-eight Dirhams and four-sevenths of a Dirham according to the most correct of the four sayings (3).
foot_note:
1. The author mentioned in (Al-Iqna' 1/13) a general rule for knowing the Two Qullas by any Ritl you want, then he elaborated on that in this treatise, saying: (If you want to know the Two Qullas by any Ritl you want, know the number of its Dirhams, then subtract it from the Dirhams of the Two Qullas time after time until nothing remains of it, and memorize the subtracted Ritls, whatever it is, is the amount of the Two Qullas by the Ritl with which you subtracted. If less than a Ritl remains, attribute it to it [as a fraction], then add it to the memorized amount) End quote.
2. The title between brackets is from the investigator for clarification.
3. Regarding the weight of the Iraqi Ritl, there are four sayings in the School; narrated in (Al-Insaf 1/122) and others: First: What the author mentioned, and corrected, that the Ritl weighs one hundred and twenty-eight Dirhams, and four-sevenths of a Dirham. He corrected it in (Al-Insaf) and said: "And upon this is the majority of the Companions", and said in (Al-Mubdi' 1/59): "And it is the famous one", and the author relied on it in (Al-Iqna' 1/13). Sheikh Taqi al-Din chose it (Majmu' Al-Fatawa 21/52, and 25/51). It is the School for the Shafi'is [Tahrir Al-Tanbih p. 110, Al-Majmu' 1/180, Al-Iqna' by Al-Shirbini 1/222], and some Maliki jurists corrected it [Mawahib Al-Jalil 2/279]. Second: That it is one hundred and twenty-eight and three-sevenths of a Dirham. [See: Sharh Al-Zarkashi 'Ala Al-Khiraqi 1/125]. He said in (Al-Insaf): "Al-Zarkashi transmitted it from the author of Al-Talkhis in it, but I did not find in the copy I have except like the previous School view" End quote. Third: That it weighs one hundred and twenty-eight Dirhams; which is in the old (Al-Mughni). It is a saying among the Malikis [See: Al-Dhakhira 3/78, Mawahib Al-Jalil 2/279], and a saying among the Shafi'i jurists [See: Al-Majmu' 1/180]. Abu Muhammad Ibn Al-Qattan said: (It is the school of the masses of scholars) [See: Takhrij Al-Dalalat Al-Sam'iyyah by Al-Khuzai p. 615]. Fourth: That it weighs one hundred and thirty Dirhams. Mentioned in (Al-Ri'ayah). It is a saying among the Malikis. See: Al-Dhakhira 3/77, Ithbat Ma Laisa Minhu Budd p. 77. It is what Al-Rafi'i mentioned in (Al-Aziz), and Ibn Al-Ukhuwwa in (Ma'alim Al-Qurba p. 82) as the saying of the Shafi'is. Al-Nawawi said in (Al-Majmu' 6/16): (It is strange and weak), and said in (I'anat Al-Talibin 1/31): (It is contrary to the relied-upon view). Ibn Al-Rif'ah said: (The transmitters differed regarding the Baghdadi Ritl. It was said: It is one hundred and twenty-eight Dirhams. And it was said: One hundred and twenty-eight Dirhams and four-sevenths of a Dirham, and this is what Al-Nawawi corrected. And it was said: One hundred and thirty Dirhams, which is what is implied by the citation of Sheikh Abu Ishaq, author of Al-Muhadhdhab. And it is the corrected view according to others, and it is what the soul feels is correct based on experience... etc.) See: Al-Idah wa Al-Tibyan fi Ma'rifat Al-Mikyal wa Al-Mizan by Ibn Al-Rif'ah p. 36, 37. Ibn Zhahira said in (Kifayat Al-Muhtaj p. 327): (It is what the soul feels is correct based on experience), then he mentioned what supports it and elaborated. Some jurists explained this view; Ibn Muflih said in (Al-Mubdi' 1/199): (The Iraqi Ritl is one hundred Dirhams and twenty-eight and four-sevenths of a Dirham, which is ninety Mithqals, and the Mithqal is a Dirham and three-sevenths of a Dirham; this was how it was of old. Then they added a Mithqal to it and made it ninety-one Mithqals, completing one hundred and thirty Dirhams, intending by that the removal of the fraction, but the practice is upon the first because it is what existed at the time the scholars estimated the Mudd with it). See: Al-Mutli' p. 8, Al-Mizan fi Al-Aqisah wa Al-Awzan by Ali Pasha Mubarak p. 89.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: And its Uqiyyah (1) is ten and five-sevenths Dirhams, which is seven and a half Mithqals. And the Ritl is ninety Mithqals (2). It—meaning the Iraqi Ritl—is one-seventh of the Damascene Ritl, and half of its seventh (3).
foot_note:
1. "Al-Uqiyyah": A unit of weight that equals forty Dirhams originally; as mentioned by Al-Khalil bin Ahmed in the book (Al-Ain 5/240). However, the Uqiyyah in Ritls differs from its estimation in the linguistic origin, as scholars agree that the Ritl is twelve Uqiyyahs. Al-Mawardi said: (And the Ritl is twelve Uqiyyahs... there is no dispute on this) [Al-Rutba p. 170]. Abu al-Abbas Ibn al-Banna al-Marrakushi (Died 721 AH) pointed out the difference in estimating the Uqiyyah of Ritls, and that it is other than the linguistic Uqiyyah, saying: (The Uqiyyah by which the Ritl is estimated. It is said: It is the weight of ten and two-thirds Dirhams, which is the view of the jurist Abu Yahya al-Mawwaq and Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Farjun... And it is said: It is ten Dirhams, which is the view of al-Dawudi). [Maqala fi Maqadir al-Makayil al-Shar'iyyah by Ibn al-Banna al-Marrakushi p. 74]. Abu Yahya al-Mawwaq (Died 599 AH) held that the Uqiyyah is ten and two-thirds Dirhams of Kayl (volume), so the Ritl contains one hundred and twenty-eight Dirhams) [Maqala fi al-Makayil wa al-Mawazin by al-Mawwaq p. 98].
2. There are opinions regarding the number of Mithqals in one Ritl: First: That it is ninety Mithqals, which is the view of the majority. Second: That it is ninety-one Mithqals. And other things were said. See: Al-Insaf 1/122, Mughni al-Muhtaj 1/383.
3. Al-Mardawi said in (Al-Insaf 1/122): (The correct view of the School is that the Iraqi Ritl is one-seventh of the Damascene Ritl and half of its seventh, and upon this is the majority of the Companions). He also said it in (Al-Mubdi' 1/59), (Al-Durr Al-Naqi 1/50), and (Ghayat Al-Muttalib p. 33).

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: And six-sevenths of the Egyptian, and a quarter of its seventh (1). And this is better than his saying in (Al-Tanqih) (2): (Half of it, a quarter of it, and a seventh of it). Even if their meaning is one; because the fraction if it is of one genus is better than being of [mixed] genera. And four-sevenths of the Laythi (3) and half of its seventh. And three-sevenths of the Alexandrian. And one-seventh of the Baalbaki (4). And three [quarters] (5) of a seventh of the Tabarani (6) (a Ritl dealt with in the land of Safad (7). And one-seventh of the Raqqi (8), and seven-eighths of its seventh.
foot_note:
1. See Al-Iqna' 1/13.
2. Al-Tanqih Al-Mushbi', by Ala' al-Din Al-Mardawi p. 33.
3. Attributed to (Munyat al-Layth) from the works of Al-Gharbia in Egypt [Hashiyat Ma'alim Al-Qurba p. 82].
4. See Al-Iqna' 1/13.
5. In the original [sevenths], and the correction is what is established; based on what the author will mention in the calculation.
6. "Tabaran": A town from the towns of Palestine, located on the Sea of Galilee which was known as (Lake Tiberias) in the Jordan Valley.
7. He said in (Mu'jam Al-Buldan 3/412): ("Safad" with vowel movement is a city in the mountains of Amilah overlooking Homs in the Levant, and it is from the mountains of Lebanon). The meaning is that this Ritl is used in these regions. As for the Safadi Ritl, it will come later.
8. "Al-Raqqa": A city located east of Aleppo on the Euphrates River.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: [Its Equation with the Damascene Ritl and what matches it] (1) The method of knowing the Iraqi by the Ritl weighing six hundred Dirhams (which is the Damascene) (2) and its Uqiyyah is fifty Dirhams: is to add to the Iraqi number half of it, then take a seventh of the total, so whatever the number reaches is the Damascene. Example: In the Two Qullas, add to them two hundred and fifty, that reaches seven hundred [and fifty, then take a seventh of that, it reaches one hundred] (3) and seven, and a seventh of a Ritl (4); and that is the amount of the Two Qullas in the Damascene (5).
foot_note:
1. The title between brackets is from the investigator for clarification.
2. Al-Rutba by Al-Mawardi p. 170, Nihayat Al-Rutba by Al-Shirazi p. 15, Ma'alim Al-Qurba by Ibn Al-Ukhuwwa p. 82. See: Hashiyat Ibn Abidin 2/365, Kifayat Al-Muhtaj 1/382, Hashiyat Al-Bajirami 'Ala Al-Iqna' 2/20, Al-Fatawa Al-Kubra by Ibn Taymiyyah 1/221, Hawashi Al-Iqna' by Al-Bahuti 1/66. Ibn Abidin Al-Dimashqi commented after mentioning this view saying: (The commentator stated... that the Shami [Damascene] Ritl is six hundred Dirhams... and based on this, the Sa' in the Shami Ritl is a Ritl and a half... And I saw this also written in the handwriting of the Sheikh of our Sheikhs Ibrahim Al-Saehani and the Sheikh of our Sheikhs Mulla Ali Al-Turkmani, and they suffice as role models. However, I calculated half a Sa' in the year 1226 and found it to be two-eights and about two-thirds of an eighth, so it is approximately a Mudd, leveled without heaping. This does not contradict what passed, because the Mudd in our time is larger than the previous Mudd, and likewise the Ritl in our time exceeds seven hundred Dirhams. This is based on estimating the Sa' with mung beans or lentils, but regarding estimating it with wheat or barley, which is more precautious as will come shortly, half a Sa' exceeds that). Ibn Badran Al-Dimashqi (Died 1346 AH) said: (The Damascene Ritl of old was six hundred Dirhams, and it is now eight hundred Dirhams). See: His Hashiyah on Akhsar Al-Mukhtasarat p. 132. This indicates that the Damascene Ritl's estimation changed with the change of time, and thus the resolution to Ibn Abidin's confusion appears.
3. What is between the brackets is missing from the original, and is necessary for the statement to make sense. The correction is benefited from (Al-Iqna') by the author, and the following sources.
4. A similar estimation is in: Al-Furu' 1/87, Al-Mubdi' 1/59, Al-Insaf 1/122, Sharh Al-Muntaha, and Al-Rawd Al-Nadi 1/27. In (Al-Umdah by Al-Muwaffaq Ibn Qudamah p. 3): (The Two Qullas are what approximates one hundred and eight Ritls in the Damascene). This indicates that it is by approximation not exactness; as Ibn Bassam said in (His Hashiyah on Al-Umdah).
5. He said in (Sharh Al-Muntaha): (And what matches it in its amount, like the Safadi).

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: And if you wish, take a seventh of the Iraqi, and half of its seventh, so whatever it reaches is the Damascene. And if you wish, drop from the Iraqi five-sevenths of it, and half of its seventh, so the remainder is the Damascene. And likewise whatever matches the Ritl of Damascus; like Safad (1). [Its Equation with the Jerusalemite Ritl and what matches it] (2) The method of knowing it by the Ritl weighing eight hundred Dirhams (which is the Jerusalemite/Qudsi) (3)
foot_note:
1. And Acre, and Sidon. [Kashshaf Al-Qina' 1/43].
2. The title between brackets is from the investigator for clarification.
3. Similarly the Khalili [Al-Rutba p. 170, Ma'alim Al-Qurba p. 82].

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: and what matches it; like the Nabulsi (1), and the Himsi (2), and its Uqiyyah is sixty-six and two-thirds Dirhams: is to add to the Iraqi number a like amount of its eighth, then take a seventh of the total, so whatever numbers it reaches is the Jerusalemite. Example: In the Two Qullas, add to the five hundred its eighth; which is sixty-two and four-sevenths, then take a seventh of the total, it reaches eighty Ritls and a seventh (3) of a Ritl, and half a seventh of a Ritl, and that is the Two Qullas in the Jerusalemite Ritl (4). And if you wish, take from the Iraqi its seventh, and an eighth of its seventh, so whatever it reaches is the Jerusalemite.
foot_note:
1. The author mentioned in (Hawashi Al-Tanqih p. 78), and Al-Bahuti in (Kashshaf Al-Qina' 3/401) that the Jerusalemite Ritl matches the Nabulsi Ritl; as the author mentioned here.
2. The author mentioned it thus in (Hawashi Al-Tanqih p. 78) that the Himsi is like the Jerusalemite. Al-Bahuti mentioned in (Kashshaf Al-Qina' 3/401) that the Himsi Ritl matches the Aleppine Ritl so its Uqiyyah equals sixty Dirhams; as will come. Al-Mawardi mentioned in (Al-Rutba p. 170) that the Himsi Ritl equals nine hundred and forty-four Dirhams. Al-Shirazi mentioned in (Nihayat Al-Rutba p. 16): That the Himsi is eight hundred and sixty-four Dirhams. According to Ibn Al-Ukhuwwa (Ma'alim Al-Qurba p. 82) the Himsi equals seven hundred and ninety-four Dirhams. So it needs verification.
3. In the original [two sevenths], and the correction is from (Al-Iqna') by the author, and the following sources.
4. He said in (Al-Mubdi' 1/59): "The Two Qullas in the Jerusalemite are eighty Ritls and a seventh of a Ritl and half a seventh". And in (Sharh Al-Muntaha): "And they are eighty Ritls and two-sevenths and half a seventh of a Jerusalemite Ritl and what matches it like the Nabulsi and Himsi". Similar is in (Al-Kashshaf 1/43).

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: And if you wish, drop from the Iraqi five-sevenths of it, and seven-eighths of its seventh / [48/b] so what remains is the Jerusalemite, and likewise what matches it. [Its Equation with the Aleppine Ritl and what matches it] (1) The method of knowing it by the Ritl weighing seven hundred and twenty Dirhams (which is the Aleppine (Halabi) (2), and the Beiruti, and the Hamawi (3) and its Uqiyyah is sixty Dirhams: is to add to the Iraqi a like amount of its quarter, then take a seventh of the total, so whatever number it reaches is the Aleppine. Example in the Two Qullas: Add to the five hundred one hundred and twenty-five, then take a seventh of that, it reaches eighty-nine and two-sevenths of a Ritl; which is the Two Qullas in the Aleppine (4). And if you wish, drop from the Iraqi five-sevenths of it and three-quarters of its seventh, so the remainder is the Aleppine. And likewise what matches it.
foot_note:
1. The title between brackets is from the investigator for clarification.
2. Thus in (Ma'alim Al-Qurba p. 82). In (Nihayat Al-Rutba by Al-Shirazi p. 16) the Aleppine is seven hundred and twenty-four Dirhams.
3. In (Nihayat Al-Rutba p. 16) and also in (Ma'alim Al-Qurba p. 82) the Hamawi equals six hundred and sixty Dirhams.
4. He said in (Al-Mubdi' 1/59): "The Two Qullas in the Aleppine are eighty-nine Ritls and two-sevenths of a Ritl". And in (Sharh Al-Muntaha): "And they are eighty-nine Ritls and two-sevenths of an Aleppine Ritl, and what matches it like the Beiruti". Similar is in (Al-Iqna', and Al-Kashshaf 1/43). The author mentioned in (Hawashi Al-Tanqih p. 78) that the Beiruti is like the Aleppine.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: [Its Equation with the Egyptian Ritl and what matches it] (1) The method of knowing it by the Ritl weighing one hundred and forty-four Dirhams (which is the Egyptian (2) and what matches it; like the Makki, and the Madani (3) —City of the Prophet PBUH—) and its Uqiyyah is twelve Dirhams: is to add to the Iraqi five times its amount, and a like amount of its quarter, then take a seventh of the total, so whatever number it reaches is the Egyptian. Example in the Two Qullas: Add to the five hundred five times its amount, that reaches three thousand, then a quarter of the five hundred which is one hundred and twenty-five, the total with it reaches three thousand one hundred and twenty-five, then take a seventh of that; which is four hundred forty-six and three-sevenths, and that is the Two Qullas in the Egyptian Ritl (4). And if you wish, take six-sevenths of the Iraqi and a quarter of its seventh, so whatever it reaches is the Egyptian.
foot_note:
1. The title between brackets is from the investigator for clarification.
2. And thus also in: Al-Rutba by Al-Mawardi p. 170, Nihayat Al-Rutba by Al-Shirazi p. 16, Ma'alim Al-Qurba by Ibn Al-Ukhuwwa p. 82. Fath Al-Qadir by Ibn Al-Humam 7/17, Al-Bahr Al-Ra'iq by Ibn Nujaym 6/141, Al-Fatawa Al-Kubra by Ibn Taymiyyah 1/221.
3. He said in (Kashshaf Al-Qina' 3/401): (The Egyptian Ritl and what matches it like the Makki and the Madani). The author also mentioned this in (Hawashi Al-Tanqih p. 78).
4. He said in (Al-Mubdi' 1/59): "The Two Qullas in the Egyptian are four hundred and forty-six Ritls and three-sevenths of a Ritl". And in (Sharh Al-Muntaha): "And the Two Qullas are four hundred Ritls and forty-six Ritls and three-sevenths of an Egyptian Ritl and what matches it like the Makki and the Madani". See Kashshaf Al-Qina' 1/43.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: And if you wish, drop from the Iraqi three-quarters of its seventh, so whatever it reaches is the Egyptian. [Its Equation with the Laythi Ritl and what matches it] (1) The method of knowing it by the Ritl weighing two hundred Dirhams (which is the Laythi) (2) which the people of Egypt also deal with, but the preceding Ritl is more famous among them, and its Uqiyyah is sixteen and two-thirds Dirhams: is to add to the Iraqi number three times its amount, and a like amount of its half, then take a seventh of the total, so whatever it reaches is the Laythi. Example in the Two Qullas: [49/a] Add to the five hundred one thousand five hundred, that becomes two thousand, then add the amount of half the five hundred; which is two hundred and fifty, the total of that reaches two thousand two hundred and fifty, then take its seventh which is three hundred [and] twenty-one and three-sevenths of a Ritl (3) and that is the amount of the Two Qullas in the Laythi. text: Praise be to Allah. What is your opinion regarding dates if they are kneaded (Jubila) (1) and pressed upon with feet (2), until some of it enters into others, is it valid to sell it for meat on credit (Nasi'ah)? If you say: It is not valid. Then what are the consequences for the one dealing in it after knowing the prohibition of that? The Answer: If one sells a volume-measured item (Makyul) for a weighed item (Mawzun) on credit, it is permissible (3). As for the Ajwa (4), if it is before it is kneaded (5) and before the mixing of some of it
foot_note:
1. (Jubila) meaning kneaded.
2. Meaning the dates are kneaded with feet, so the dates become like dough, which is what is called among us as (Al-Abit), and some nowadays call it in the markets (Ma'jun Al-Tamr/Date Paste). This type cannot be imagined to be measured by volume, but only by weight.
3. See: Kashshaf Al-Qina' 8/10.
4. It came in the book "Al-'Aami Al-Fasih" from the publications of the Language Academy in Cairo the text: (Al-Ajwa: A type of the finest dates in Madinah. And the common people define Ajwa as dates that are mixed one part with another and piled up). The second meaning is the author's intent, for he means by Ajwa the dates if mixed before kneading, so the author's usage is indeed the colloquial usage of the word, not the classical one. As for our time now, some people do not call dates "Ajwa" unless after kneading, so (Ajwa) is written on kneaded dates. So be aware of this difference in the usage of the word.
5. The style expressed by the author is one of the uncommon styles, where he entered (An) the infinitive particle on the conjugatable past verb. It is a dialect permitted by some grammarians. Al-Zawawi said in (Nazm Qawa'id Al-I'rab): (An) is a particle of infinitude that makes the imperfect accusative ... And the saying regarding it meeting the past tense is disturbed. And (An) here can be interpreted as a source (Masdar), so the sentence is: (Before its kneading); evidenced by the fact that he conjoined it with a source (Masdar) which is his saying: (Before mixing).

text: with the other and pressing upon it with feet, then it is permissible in both cases; since at that time it is volume-measured dates (1), and meat is weighed, so selling it on credit is permissible. But after its kneading, it no longer remains capable of being measured by volume, nor is it called volume-measured (Makyul), even if its origin was volume-measured, but rather it is weighed. So if it becomes weighed, it is not permissible to exchange one for the other on credit; because it is selling a weighed item for a weighed item on credit. And if the truth becomes apparent, it must be followed (2). Perhaps the Fatwa of our Sheikh Al-Shuwayki (3), and Ahmed bin Yahya (4), regarding that are interpreted based on this (5).
foot_note:
1. Because the dates did not cease being volume-measured dates even if their types were mixed, and did not become just one type.
2. So the author interpreted it based on the difference of the state, and the reality of his opinion is preferring the view of Ibn Atwa over the view of Al-Shuwayki, may Allah the Almighty have mercy on them.
3. Sheikh Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Ahmed Al-Shuwayki Al-Hanbali (875 - 939 AH).
4. He is: The scholar Sheikh Ahmed bin Yahya bin Atwa bin Zaid Al-Tamimi Al-Hanbali, died in the year 948 AH and was buried in Al-Jubaylah. See: Unwan Al-Majd by Ibn Bishr p. 10.
5. Meaning the difference between the two Sheikhs is interpreted based on the difference of the state. Al-Shuwayki's prohibition of weighing Ajwa is before its kneading and mixing, so it remains volume-measured, and thus there is no Riba in selling it for meat. As for Ibn Atwa, he validates weight in Ajwa, the place of which is after kneading and mixing, so the dates become weighed at that point, so Riba applies to it with meat.

book_title: A Collection Containing Four Treatises by Al-Hajjawi
text: So the Fatwa of Al-Shuwayki (1) is interpreted regarding Ajwa before kneading it, and the Fatwa of Ibn Yahya (2) (3) after kneading it.
foot_note:
1. Sheikh Uthman Ibn Bishr said in (Unwan Al-Majd p. 10): (A conflict and quarrel occurred between Ibn Atwa and Al-Shuwayki, and Ibn Atwa authored a work refuting him in his Fatwa that kneaded dates if kneaded do not leave the rationale (Illah) of volume-measure. Likewise, something similar occurred between him and Abdullah bin Rahma, so Sheikh Ibn Atwa refuted him... And his refutation in that was recorded by Judge Ibn al-Qadi Ali bin Zaid the Judge of Ajwad bin Zamil the ruler of Al-Ahsa, and Judge Abdul Qadir bin Yazid Al-Musharrafi, and Judge Mansour bin Musbih Al-Bahili, and Abdul Rahman bin Musbih Al-Bahili, and Abdul Rahman bin Musbih, and Judge Ahmed bin Fayrouz bin Bassam, and Sultan bin Rayyis bin Mughamis, and all of these were in the time of Ajwad bin Zamil Al-Amiri Al-Uqayli the King of Al-Ahsa). Sheikh Abdullah Ibn Bassam indicated in (Ulama Najd 1/449) in the biography of Ibn Atwa, this Fatwa saying: (And a debate took place between the subject and his colleague Sheikh Ahmed Al-Shuwayki Al-Nabulsi—who was his peer under their Sheikh: Ahmed Al-Askari—, just as a similar one occurred between him and Sheikh Abdullah bin Rahma Al-Nasiri, regarding kneaded dates, do they remain on their original standard as volume-measured or does their standard become weight? The subject supported the second view, and they opposed him in that, and the debate intensified between him and them, so he authored a refutation against them regarding that).
2. The text of Sheikh Ahmed bin Yahya Ibn Atwa's words is: (If it is said: It follows from your saying the permissibility of selling kneaded dates for wheat and the like of volume-measured items on credit; due to the difference of the rationale (Illah). I said: It implies analogy in appearance. But the verification: is the prevention of analogy; due to the lack of unity of the two rationales; for the rationale with which selling two genuses one for the other is prohibited is the original rationale, not the incidental rationale. And because it blocks the means to Riba, for selling volume-measured dates for volume-measured items on credit is prohibited by agreement, so the one who wants that can remove dates from their attribute by kneading, to arrive by that to other than its place, and to his corrupt intent of Riba; and because a thing is not sold for what shared its origin on credit). See: Al-Fawakih Al-Adida 1/250, Mulakhkhas Al-Fawakih Al-Adida 1/158. There are some phrases I corrected from the Summary (Mulakhkhas).
3. Likewise Sheikh Shihab Ahmed Al-Askari Al-Hanbali (Died 910 AH) agreed with his student Sheikh Ibn Atwa. In questions asked to him by Ahmed bin Yahya bin Atwa (f. 6), Al-Askari said: (It follows from dates being kneaded that Riba applies; due to the unity of the rationale of the price and the priced item, which is weight. And the transfer of dates from volume-measure by kneading them is something on which there is no disagreement among any of the scholars, nay nor any of the rational people).

And preceding [it] with cleaning using water first ... Or the stone that cleanses, and the intention of the one purifying
And that the time enters regarding the one who has ... From urine incontinence (Aslas) and the likes of the one with harm
And sanity, emptiness from what negates his [state of Islam/purity] ... Removing what might prevent the water from running
Upon his skin like wax, then its purity ... From menses or the like, so one with ten

And the obligation of ablution is washing a face and after it ... His hands, and wiping all of the head of the one purifying

And indeed the conditions of Ghusl in the ruling, so rely ... Are eight: Sanity, and the intention of the one purifying
Except for the one who refused Ghusl for her menses ... She is washed forcefully so he may have intercourse with her upon purity
And his discernment is a condition for the validity of his Ghusl ... And pure water with its permissibility, so know

And indeed the conditions for Tayammum are six ... Sanity and discernment with the absence of Kufr
And his intention, then the entry of the time of what ... He prays, then the inability in that due to harm
To use water, then the obligation of Tayammum ... Is wiping a face then the hands with dust (Afr)
